poem:
Title: "The Dance of Democracy"

Swirling left, dodging right,
In the city's frantic dance, the hopeful stumble.
Leads are built on lies and light,
 watching the worker's platforms crumble.
Haunted in the night by past defeats,
Under the leering gaze of suburban leisure,
Yet, as the heart of democracy beats,
It's not the win, but the fight, that measures pleasure.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "A wobbly left and a wary right could cut the Labour vote with low turnout | Robert Ford Twenty-point poll leads, historic strength on all the polling indicators, a flailing opponent fighting for third place – and yet still Labour worries. It is no wonder. Dark nights of disappointment in suburban leisure centres haunt Labour nightmares, with candidates and activists cruelly betrayed by late swings and polling errors: 1970, 1992, 2015 – every generation of". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
